Message.Title: How Reagan Made Gay Marriage Possible!
Message.Msg: How Reagan Made Gay Marriage Possible! Jeffrey Toobin: "The Supreme Court's embrace of gay rights last week had an almost serene majesty. The obvious correctness of the Court's judgment, its curt dismissal of a monstrous injustice, had a grandeur that requires little elaboration. Yet the decision had its roots in something prosaic and largely forgotten: the midterm elections of 1986. Until that point in Ronald Reagan's Presidency, the loyal opposition was more loyal than opposed to the genial Californian in the White House, but Democrats came roaring back, winning control of the Senate with eight new seats." "It took Reagan and his aides some time to recognize the realignment on Capitol Hill. After the resignation of Lewis F. Powell, Jr., from the Court, in 1987, Reagan nominated Robert Bork. He would have been an ideological twin to Antonin Scalia, who had been confirmed with ease the previous year. But the Democrats in the Senate, especially the new chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Joseph Biden, picked a fight over Bork and defeated his nomination by fifty-eight to forty-two. In response, Howard Baker, the former senator turned White House chief of staff, urged Reagan to acknowledge the new political realities and make a more moderate choice. Reagan did; he selected Anthony M. Kennedy.

Topic.Title: How Reagan Made Gay Marriage Possible!

Message.Msg: During Reagan's presidency the first openly gay couple spent a night together in the White House. In a column for The Washington Post on March 18, 1984, Robert Kaiser described the sleep-over: "[The Reagans' interior decorator, Ted Grabher, who oversaw the redecoration of the White House, spent a night in the Reagans' private White House quarters with his male lover, Archie Case, when they came to Washington for Nancy Reagan's 60th birthday party. . . . Indeed, all the available evidence suggests that Ronald Reagan is a closet tolerant.

Message.Msg: (the dems wrote the legislation to double it.) Well that isn't true and you know it but the Republican "solution" was to write legislation that MORE than doubles it. The Democratic-led Senate, which is working on a plan to freeze rates at the current 3.4 percent until 2015. The non-partisan Congressional Research Service has estimated that under the Republican plan, a student who borrows the maximum amount of subsidized and unsubsidized Stafford loans over five years would pay $14,430 in interest. If rates were allowed to double on July 1, a student would pay $12,598, compared with $7,965 if rates do not double. The Republican bill costs students and families more than if the congress did nothing. Google: Obama threatens to veto Republican student loan plan

Topic.Title: why does yahoo do nothing about csco message board cesspool?

Message.Msg: I could fix the problem myself if Yahoo!'s "ignore function" worked on all posts by an unwanted poster, and that person was truly ignored across all of Yahoo!'s message boards. On the Raging Bull message board, for instance, when a poster is ignored they are gone forever!

Message.Title: Gerrymanderers on the hot seat
Message.Msg: By ALEX ISENSTADT | 7/1/13 4:59 AM EDT No one disputes Republicans used the once-a-decade redistricting process to lock in their House majority ‚Äî almost certainly through 2014 and possibly until the next round of line-drawing in 2020. But the party could pay a steep price for that dominance. Latest on POLITICO Some top GOP strategists and candidates warn that the ruby red districts the party drew itself into are pushing House Republicans further to the right ‚Äî narrowing the party‚Äôs appeal at a time when some GOP leaders say its future rests on the opposite happening. If you‚Äôre looking for a root cause of the recurring drama within the House Republican Conference ‚Äî from the surprise meltdown on the farm bill to the looming showdown over immigration reform ‚Äî the increasingly conservative makeup of those districts is a good place to start. (PHOTOS: Republicans on how to fix the GOP) The shellacking Republicans took in 2012 has triggered months of consternation that the party is too white, too conservative and too male. But tell that to the increasing number of House Republicans who are safely ensconced with nary a worry that a Democrat might unseat them in the next election. The bigger threat to them is a primary challenge from the right bankrolled by the Club for Growth or another deep-pocketed outside group angry they went soft on a key vote. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs obviously easier for a House member to focus on their district. They‚Äôre in cycle every day of the year, always on the hot seat, and there‚Äôs always a challenger around the corner,‚Äù said Matt Schlapp, who served as political director in the George W. Bush White House.

Jefferson County authorities released the identities of the three people killed in Sunday's shooting at McFaddin Beach. Deputies identified the suspected shooter as 32 year-old Eric Omar Barragan, of Bridge City. Barragan is believed to killed himself after shooting Lauren Michelle Brack, 31, and Regino Antonio Maybit, Jr., 34, both of Groves. "The shooting appears to originate from the termination of a relationship between Lauren Brack and Eric Barragan," according to a news release issued by the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office. "It appears that Maybit and Brack were currently in a relationship."The sheriff's office is asking any witnesses to contact them at 409-835-8411. Jefferson County Sheriff's Department deputies, Port Arthur police and the Coast Guard responded to reports of a shooting at McFaddin Beach in South Jefferson County on Sunday afternoon to find three persons dead upon arrival.

Message.Msg: will you be in Florence this summer, we should get together We look forward to welcoming you to Florence. Please let us know if we may be of assistance in planning your visit. If you would like to book museums, transfers and tours, please see the booking concierge attachment to this e-mail. There will be a service fee for Museum tickets. For all the clients who stay in Florence for more than 3 days you can purchase Firenze Card, which is valid for 72 hours and provides you the admission to more than 30 museums, located in Florence. You will be entitled to visit permanent collections, exhibitions and other activities held in these museums. You will avoid queues and booking limitations. You will be also enabled to use public transports free of charge. Cost includes service. If you wish arrange something special before your arrival in suite, for honeymooners, Spa reservations, cooking classes in Florence or in Tuscany don‚Äôt hesitate to contact us On request, Palazzo Magnani Feroni takes care of guests‚Äô ultimate experiences and wishes and provides access to a tailor-made Palace and Florence experience! Our dedicated and discreet staff will bring life into your plans and move mountains to make your wishes come true. I assure our best Palace service to you. We look forward to welcoming you to the Palace. Sincerely Yours, Francesca Di Marco Front Desk Palazzo Magnani Feroni -Borgo San Frediano, 5 ‚Äì 50124 Firenze Tel: +39 055 2399544, Fax +39 055 2608908 Skype: palazzo.magnani.feroni

Message.Msg: unfortunately my cousin won't be there to show us around, he has a pretty high post at the vatican, LOL Headed to Rome on July 13, back on the 18th; no August trip planned bc Mary Beth is working for one of the candidates for Mayor of Boston, the only woman in the race, and the all-important Preliminary is Sept, 25 when the field gets narrowed from 12 to 2 finalists...so it's going to be a long, hot summer. You arrive in Rome at "high noon," August 15 is the culmination of the summer with many places closed, so check with yr hotel concierge abt what is open. By far the best small museum (in the world, IMO) is the Galleria Borghese...jammed full of absolute baroque masterpieces...you need to pre-arrange tickets, cannot just walk up..you could even go online for Galleria Borghese. Don't poke around on yr own, official guides have line-jumping privileges; worth it. Be sure their vehicles (bus; can also arrange private car) have AC. St Peter, Colosseum, Roman Forum, Trevi Fountain are all musts. Sistine Chapel if you have line-jumping guide. Vatican Museum not really much. You don't have much time, but on a day-excursion basis there is the monastery of Montecassino, 2-2.5 hrs from Rome, tour buses available. Two points of note: It is/was one of the oldest monasteries of the Benedictine order; 'was' because it is on top of a hill/mountain and was bombed to smithereens by us during WWII, then rebuilt. Given yr limited time in Rome may not be worth killing an entire day, plus it will be hot. Watch out for pick-pockets, they swarm the major tourist venues. Enjoy your trip. Best
